Title: Abolition of Detrimental Observations in Child Welfare Laws

Summary:
Child abandonment is a significant concern that necessitates immediate attention and action. However, rather than focusing on detrimental observations, we should focus on abolishing child abandonment altogether. We must recognize the potential harmful impact of detrimental observations on children, who are already facing significant challenges due to abandonment. Abolishing detrimental observations will contribute to creating a more compassionate and supportive environment for children who have been abandoned and those who may face such situations in the future. It is high time we prioritize the best interests of the child and take concrete steps towards achieving this goal.

Key Points:

1. The focus should be on ending child abandonment, not on detrimental observations that may exacerbate the trauma faced by these children.
2. Abolishing detrimental observations will promote a more compassionate approach to child welfare laws.
3. Every child deserves a safe and secure childhood, free from the harsh realities of abandonment and detrimental observations.
4. It is time to prioritize the child's best interests and invest in measures that address the root causes of child abandonment.

Conclusion:
Ending child abandonment requires a comprehensive and collective approach that prioritizes the best interests of the child. Rather than engaging in detrimental observations, we must focus on creating a supportive environment that promotes the well-being and happiness of every child. By abolishing detrimental observations in child welfare laws, we can reaffirm our commitment to the protection and care of children who have been abandoned and inspire hope for a brighter future for all children who may face similar situations.

WNBA standings after a week of play
July 8, 2011 By Clark Boehme Leave a Comment
I’ll begin this post by saying that I haven’t been writing as much about WNBA as I have in the past because there hasn’t been as much happening on the court this season. However, I’ll do my best to keep you up to date with the latest developments in the league.
Today, let’s take a look at the WNBA standings after a week of play.
As of today, the standings look like this:
1. Minnesota Lynx (7-1)
2. Indiana Fever (6-1)
3. Chicago Sky (6-2)
4. Atlanta Dream (5-2)
5. Seattle Storm (4-4)
6. New York Liberty (3-5)
7. Phoenix Mercury (2-6)
8. Dallas Wings (1-8)
9. Los Angeles Sparks (1-8)
The top five teams in the standings are all within one game of each other, with Minnesota, Indiana, and Chicago all holding a game over the field. The Storm and Dream have both had a bit of a rough start to the season, sitting in the middle of the pack.
The Liberty have been one of the biggest disappointments of the season so far, sitting in last place in the East. They are 3-5 overall, with their only wins coming against the Dream, Fever, and Sky. The Mercury and Sparks are also struggling, sitting last in the West and East respectively.
It’s still early in the season, but it looks like Minnesota and Indiana are the teams to beat at this point. Let’s see how things shake out over the next few weeks.

”I Have Slept With Over 300 Women” – Billionaire Robert Kraft Boasts
Billionaire Robert Kraft, owner of the New England Patriots, has boasted of his sexual conquests and claimed to have slept with over 300 women.
Kraft, 77, made the boasts in an interview with the Palm Beach Post last month, which was published on Friday.
According to the paper, Kraft was asked how many women he had been intimate with and he replied: “You know, I really don’t think about that. I’ve been with over 300.”
Kraft, who has a net worth of $6.6 billion, also reportedly made derogatory comments about women’s looks.
When asked for comment, a representative for Kraft said in a statement: “Robert Kraft is a proud father and grandfather. His comments were private and not meant to be made public. We would suggest that the media focus on more important things.”
Kraft, who is one of the NFL’s most high-profile owners, has faced a number of controversies in recent years, including a prostitution investigation which resulted in him being charged with two counts of soliciting prostitution at Jupiter, Florida’s Orchids of Asia Day Spa in 2019.
He denied any wrongdoing and the case was later dismissed after the alleged victim refused to cooperate with investigators.

DECISION AND ORDER
This case is before the Authority on appeal from the
Regional Director of the Federal Labor Relations Authority
for the Atlantic Region. The case involves a dispute between
the Veterans Administration Medical Center, Pittsburgh
(Employer) and American Federation of Government Employees
Local 1667 (Union) concerning the ground rules for
collective bargaining.
It appears that the Employer and the Union have reached an
agreement concerning the ground rules for collective
bargaining between the parties. The matter was submitted to
the Regional Director of the Authority for a decision. The
Regional Director issued an order finding that the agreement
was contrary to the requirements of the Federal Labor
Relations Authority's Rules and Regulations and ordering
the agreement rescinded.
The Union appealed the Regional Director's decision to the
Authority. For the reasons set forth below, we find that
the Regional Director's decision should be set aside.
II. Discussion
It is well settled that the Authority's Rules and
Regulations do not prescribe the ground rules for collective
bargaining between an agency and a labor organization.
Rather, the Authority's Rules and Regulations are intended
to ensure that the parties are able to engage in collective
bargaining in an atmosphere of stability and to facilitate
the resolution of disputes arising under the Statute.
In this case, the Employer and the Union have reached an
agreement concerning the ground rules for collective
bargaining between the parties. The agreement was submitted
to the Regional Director of the Authority for a decision.
The Regional Director ordered the agreement rescinded
finding that it was contrary to the requirements of the

HANSON v. CRAWFORD COUNTY HOSPITAL(1939)
[302 U.S. 158, 159] Mr. W. A. Thompson, of Lexington, Ky., for petitioner.
Messrs. John T. Caldwell and J. C. Doolittle, both of Louisville, Ky., for respondent.
This is a bill in equity filed by a former employee of the petitioner to enjoin the seizure and sale of personal property owned by the petitioner and alleged to be liable to attachment under an attachment sued out against the petitioner by respondent, the Crawford County Hospital, upon a judgment rendered against the petitioner in an action brought by respondent to recover the value of medical services rendered to certain hospital patients by the petitioner during the period of her employment. The property is described as two surplus motor trucks, a pickup truck, a 1938 model Fordson tractor and a set of tools. The bill prays for a decision that the property is not liable to attachment, or in the alternative, for the appointment of a receiver to take charge of the property and to dispose of it in such manner as the court may direct.
The case was submitted upon the pleadings, and the decree appealed from was entered dismissing the bill. The sole question presented by the appeal is whether the bill is properly dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
The petitioner, who was a resident of Kentucky, was employed as a public welfare worker by the respondent, the Crawford County Hospital, a corporation organized under the laws of Kentucky, and was assigned to service in Cave City, Ky. She was at all times here material a member of a class of employees regularly employed by the respondent upon public health projects. The petitioner alleges that she was paid a salary by the respondent in the usual course of its business as a provider of medical services, and that the salary was withheld as a trust fund under the terms of an agreement between the petitioner and the respondent.
